column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Dougga

#Text=Dougga is a small town in the north of Tunisia that holds the extensive ruins of a Roman town , set on a hilltop , overlooking surrounding valleys with olive plantations , featured on the UNESCO World Heritage list .
#Text=It also has several other monuments dating from pre-Roman times .
#Text=Plan to spend about 2 hours here , and if you have a car , couple it with trips to surrounding areas ( ask the security guard at the ticket office for recommendations ) .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The road to Dougga passes through beautiful rural and scenic landscape .

#Text=Unlike Roman ruins in Carthage or even in European towns where one or two remaining monuments are isolated in the middle of a modern city , at Dougga , the entire town is preserved , even the Roman streets .
#Text=Without the barriers and the flocks of tourists , one can take one 's time to climb in and out of houses and tunnels , temples and the theatres .
#Text=As with other sites in Tunis , Dougga 's history is not limited to only the Roman period .
#Text=One finds an old Punic temple here with a cleansing bath and walls from the Phoenician period , which was later transformed and reused by the Romans , and thus has Roman pillars .
#Text=There is also an obvious funerary monument , the Mausoleum of Ateban , dating to 2nd century BCE , one of three examples of royal Numidian architecture .
#Text=Its inscription is housed in the British Museum , and the Punic-Libyan bilingual inscription was used to translate Libyan script .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Get a bus ( at least two hours ) or louage ( 80 minutes ) to Teboursouk ( pronouned Tebsook ) from Bab Saadoune louage/bus station ( Gare de Routiere Nord ) in Tunis .
#Text=A taxi will take you the short distance to Dougga and then pick you up again at an arranged time .
#Text=Louage drivers often ring ahead to alert the taxi that a tourist is arriving .
#Text=It 's very convenient and quick but 15-20 DT for only a short distance .
#Text=If you ca n't manage to get the price down , remember that Dougga is a memorable place to visit and well worth the money .
#Text=As of July 2016 there was only one , extremely busy , taxi in Teboursouk that also served as the local bus , so arguing with the driver over the price was pointless .
#Text=Use return taxi trip to get to Teboursouk because there will almost certainly be no taxis waiting to pick up passengers leaving Dougga ( as it is in the middle of nowhere ) .
#Text=If driving , clear sign posts pointing to the Ruins of Dougga can be followed from Tebersouk .
#Text=You could also go as part of an organised tour from Tunis .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Light sandals might not be the best footwear as the paths are , for the most part , cobbled and can be reasonably steep in places .
#Text=See
#Text=There are lots of buildings still partially standing .
#Text=There are also few restrictions as to where you can walk .
#Text=The following is a suggested route to visit .
#Text=Entry is 7 DT plus 1 DT for photography ( as of 2018 ) .
#Text=Theater .
#Text=Built in 168 or 169 CE , is one of the best preserved examples in Roman Africa .
#Text=It could seat 3500 spectators , and is the first thing one sees on entering the site .
#Text=From here continue on to the capitol , which has great monolithic columns that cannot be missed .
#Text=Roads .
#Text=On the main roads ( the broad road to Carthage for example ) , one can see cut outs for horses not to slip , and holes in the remaining door ways to tie the horses to .
#Text=Under the roads are the Roman sewers - various stones on the main road can be lifted up to let the water out in times of flooding .
#Text=Mosque .
#Text=Tiny building with Roman columns in the interior to the left of the capitol when coming from the theatre .
#Text=Marketplace .
#Text=Note the marks in the floor where the shop doors used to go .
#Text=Square of the Rose of the Winds .
#Text=Look out for the markings on the floor with the 12 winds - especially the winds bringing rain from the north .
#Text=The Capitol .
#Text=A Roman temple from the 2nd century CE , principally dedicated to Rome ’s protective triad :
#Text=Jupiter Optimus Maximus , Juno Regina et Minerva Augusta .
#Text=Located next to the marketplace and the forum .
#Text=Forum .
#Text=Note the statue with the images of four gods on two sides .
#Text=The arch of Alexander Septimius .
#Text=Can be seen from far as it is well preserved .
#Text=On the road towards Theveste , in Algeria ( 300km ) .
#Text=The temple of Caelaestis .
#Text=A little way off , through a grove of olive trees , and there is a sign pointing the way .
#Text=It is dedicated to Juno Caelestis , the successor of the Punic god Tanit .
#Text=Its well-preserved temenos is demarcated by a Phoenician wall , a large section of which has been very well preserved .
#Text=The interior has Roman columns .
#Text=On the right side is a small pit used for purification in Punic times .
#Text=Dar Lacheb .
#Text=Back on the main road to Carthage is a sanctuary , a temple , a gymnasium ?
#Text=A perfectly preserved door in any case !
#Text=Two stretches of grass on the inside of this area .
#Text=Antonian Baths .
#Text=Three rooms - for hot , warm and cold baths .
#Text=In the center of the city area and was used in winter .
#Text=Two other baths exist , one outside the city center for the summer .
#Text=Pass through the tunnels where the slaves used to heat the water to get to the three baths .
#Text=From the room for rest with the metal grids on the floor and the mosaics , climb up the steep steps to get back to the Capitol .
#Text=Brothel .
#Text=Facing the valley , somewhat halfway between Dar Lacheb and the Mausoleum of Ateban , is the brothel - many small chambers around a main court .
#Text=You can get to it by passing through the smaller theatre that is just below the area towards the valley , upon exiting the steps .
#Text=Mausoleum of Ateban .
#Text=Septimius Severus 's arch .
#Text=From the brothel , continue back towards the main exit and you 'll reach the arch of Septimius Severus - two stumps left , but majestic .
#Text=On the road that leads towards Carthage ( 120km ) .
